rest.sentence: For solution prepared perovskite solar cells, metal halide perovskite materials with low-dimensional  are flexibly employed in 3D perovskite solar cells to promote efficiency and long-term stability
In this review, the various structures, properties, and applications of LD perovskites are firstly summarized and discussed

To take advantage of LD materials, LD perovskites are introduced in the 3D bulk and/or the interface between the perovskite thin film and the carrier transporting layer to passivate the gain boundary defects while providing the stability advantage of LD materials
Therefore, the preparation methods and crystallization control of the LD perovskite layers are discussed in depth

Then, the combined devices using both LD and 3D components are reviewed on the basis of device design, cell structure, interface charge transfer, energy lever alignment, and synergistic improvement of both efficiency and stability
Finally, the challenges and expectations are speculated for further development of perovskite solar cells.
Low-dimensional perovskite materials  are widely flexible and employed in 3D perovskite solar cells to promote efficiency and long-term stability.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image
Lili Gao received her Ph.D
degree in materials science and engineering from Xi’an Jiaotong University in 2019
She worked as a visiting scholar from 2018 to 2019 in the Professor Mercouri G
Kanatzidis group at Northwestern University
She works as a postdoc researcher at Shaanxi Normal University with Prof
Shengzhong  Liu from 2020 to 2022
Now she is an associate professor at Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology
Her research is mainly focused on multiple dimensional perovskite materials and their optoelectronic applications.
Ping Hu received his Ph.D
degree in materials science from the University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2011

He is a full professor at the School of Metallurgical Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, and the National and Local Joint Engineering Research Center for Functional Materials Processing
He has long been engaged in the research of powder metallurgy and nano-functional materials.
Shengzhong  Liu received his Ph.D
degree from Northwestern University  in 1992

After finishing his postdoctoral research at Argonne National Laboratory , he joined high-tech companies in the US for research including nanoscale materials, thin film solar cells, laser processing and diamond thin films
In 2011, he was selected into China’s top talent recruitment program, and now he is a professor at Shaanxi Normal University and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
